Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Woo \Woo\, v. t. [imp. & p. p. {Wooed}; p. pr. & vb. n. {Wooing}.] [OE. wowen, wo?en, AS. w?gian, fr. w?h bent, crooked, bad; akin to OS. w[=a]h evil, Goth. unwahs blameless, Skr. va?c to waver, and perhaps to E. vaccilate.] [1913 Webster] 1. To solicit in love; to court. [1913 Webster]
Each, like the Grecian artist, wooes The image he himself has wrought. --Prior. [1913 Webster]
2. To court solicitously; to invite with importunity. [1913 Webster]
Thee, chantress, oft the woods among I woo, to hear thy even song. --Milton. [1913 Webster]
I woo the wind That still delays his coming. --Bryant. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Woo \Woo\, v. i. To court; to make love. --Dryden. [1913 Webster]
woo v 1: seek someone's favor; "China is wooing Russia" [syn: {court}] 2: make amorous advances towards; "John is courting Mary" [syn: {court}, {romance}, {solicit}]
